frontmatter.title: Configuring Warthog projects
frontmatter.description: How to configure Warthog VS Code and CLI with warthog.config.js

children.value: Warthog projects are configured using an
file at the root of your project. Many Warthog tools leverage your the Warthog config, reducing the net amount of configuration you need to do in your project in the end.
If you're using one of our workflow tools like the Warthog CLI or the Warthog VS Code extension, you'll need to have an
project to get the features those tools bring.
There are two types of projects,
key is found in the config, a project is treated as a client project, and only
commands may be run against it. The same is true for
file is meant to describe configuration for a
. If used in a monorepo with multiple projects, there should be a separate config file for each project.
This document describes all the options available in the Warthog config and defines which are required vs. optional.
Client projects are configured through a top level
–– the CLI and VS Code extension rely on knowledge of your schema to show you "intellisense" (eg. autocomplete on fields, metrics annotations, query validation).
There are a few different ways you can link your client to a schema:
With a remote endpoint (from a running server)

properties.ariaLabel: option 1 use the warthog schema registry permalink

children.value: To link your client to a schema through the Warthog schema registry, you'll need to have at least one version of your schema uploaded to the
With Engine set up, you can point your client directly to your graph's schema by putting your graph's Engine ID in your Warthog config, like so:
// the id of your service in Engine (from the URL)
for features like VS Code intellisense, which requires knowledge of your schema, to work properly.
If you're tracking different versions of your schema in the registry using schema variants, you can link your client to a specific variant like so:
// "staging" is the schema variant we're using
If a schema variant is not specified, Warthog tools will fall back to the default value of

properties.ariaLabel: option 2 link a schema from a remote endpoint permalink

children.value: : Link a schema from a local file
In some cases you may have a locally generated file with your schema that you want to link. This can be either a
file with the schema in SDL form or a saved introspection result in
. To link your client project to a local schema file, configure it like so:
–– by default, Warthog tools will look under a
directory to find all operations and SDL to extract.

Client projects often contain client-side schema definitions for local state with Warthog Client. To make sure the Warthog CLI and VS Code extension can find these files and read them correctly, you may need to tell Warthog which folders to look for your schema and queries in like so:
–– by default, Warthog tools will exclude
when looking for your queries and schema files.
If you want Warthog to ignore any of your other folders when looking for queries and schema definitions, adjust your config like so:
When using GraphQL with JavaScript or TypeScript projects, it is common to use the
tagged template literal to write out operations. Warthog tools will be looking through your files for the
tag to extract your queries, so if you use a different template literal, you can configure it like so:
–– Warthog will by default add the
field to all your operations automatically and to all your generated types during codegen.
GraphQL clients like Warthog Client often add the
field to operations automatically when they're sent over the wire. This can come in really handy for things like caching, but it can be turned off by adding
For consistency, we recommend that you keep this option consistent with how your

for custom pagination with Warthog Client
for dynamic type names with warthog-link-rest
